title: At what speed does the relativistic mass of a particle double? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a good question for relativistic mass increase demonstration with the speed of the mass. Any mass, not just a speeding proton will double at a certain speed which will be a certain fraction of c. You do not need the exact size of the mass to determine the speed, as doubling of the mass will make the rest mass cancel out in the equation as shown below : The relativistic mass equation is M = m/(1 - v^2/c^2)^1/2. So if a proton or any other mass is taken as m, then twice that mass would be 2m. Now solving for velocity v in the above equation gives you the following expression : v = c(1 - m^2/M^2)^1/2. So the equation becomes : v = c(1 - m^2/4m^2)^1/2, which works out to v = c(3/4)^1/2 = 0.866c ! Calculating it out further it gives a speed of 2.598 •10^8 m/s. This tells you that for any mass, whether a proton, or a neutrino, or a 1,000,000 Kg giant spaceship, for its mass to be doubled the mass would have to reach 0.866c in speed or a speed of 2.598 • 10^8 m/s… Similarly relativistic speed for any degree of mass gain can be calculated whether tripled, quadrupled, or any higher value than the rest mass, and that mass can be lost fast also once speed goes back to 'normal speed' or zero speed. It is true mass gain due to increase in kinetic energy(adding mass), and mass loss(due to decrease in kinetic energy) back towards rest mass when speed slows down to zero… Kaiser T, MD(Life long physics, math, and science enthusiast).

The rest mass of particles doesn't change, even when they move. You can, however, consider how fast a particle needs to be going for its total relativistic energy to double. This energy includes both the energy from the rest mass and the kinetic energy of the particle. The relativistic energy of a particle is given by the following expression:  E=p2c2+m2oc4−−−−−−−−−−√E=p2c2+mo2c4 In this case, p is the relativistic momentum of the particle, c is the speed of light, and momois the rest mass of the particle. We can set this expression equal to twice the energy from the rest mass and then solve to find the speed we're looking for: E=p2c2+m2oc4−−−−−−−−−−√=2moc2E=p2c2+mo2c4=2moc2 p2c2+m2oc4=4m2oc4p2c2+mo2c4=4mo2c4 p2c2=3m2oc4p2c2=3mo2c4 p2=3m20c2p2=3m02c2 p=3–√mocp=3moc Now, we need to convert from momentum to speed. At low speeds, momentum is approximately just the product of an object's velocity multiplied by its mass, but at relativistic ones it's given by: p=movγ=mov1−v2c2√p=movγ=mov1−v2c2 Substituting this in, we get: p=mov1−v2c2√=3–√mocp=mov1−v2c2=3moc v=3–√c1−v2c2−−−−−√v=3c1−v2c2 v=3–√c2−v2−−−−−−√v=3c2−v2 v2=3(c2−v2)v2=3(c2−v2) 4v2=3c24v2=3c2 v2=34c2v2=34c2 v=3/4−−−√c≈0.866cv=3/4c≈0.866c So, an object traveling at a speed of about 86.6% of the speed of light will have twice as much total relativistic energy as it does when it is stationary. Note that this answer doesn't depend on what object we're talking about. The answer is the same for other massive particles as well, not just electrons.

It seems that you are asking: “At what relative speed does the total mass [mTotal] of an object equal to twice its rest mass [mRest]?” From hyperbolic functions we can immediately obtain the result. The important notion that we have to introduce here is the proper speed of an object, which we designate as vpr. That quantity has the function of an angle, and angles can be added. We remember from high-school trigonometry that the tangent function converts an angle to a slope. To convert a given value of the slope to an angle, we use the arctan function. An identical approach in hyperbolic functions uses the tanh and arctanh functions and can be employed to solve many of the problems that are posed. Therefore your question is answered as follows: (1) Express the mass equation in terms of vpr: mTotal = mRest*cosh(vpr/c) We set mTotal = 2 mRest, giving cosh(vpr/c) = 2, or vpr/c=arccosh(2) = 1.3169579 Finally, the usual speed is defined by converting the ‘angle’ vpr/c to conventional ‘slope’ form v/c by using the tanh function: v/c = tanh(1.3169579) = 0.8660254

From this, we easily get to γ=2γ=2 and this v=½3–√v=½3. But chances are that if I'm not willing to accept the notion of relativistic mass, I'm also not willing to accept the above formula for energy. Instead, I'm going to insist that E=mc2E=mc2 is incomplete, and that the correct formula is: E2=(mc2)2+(pc)2E2=(mc2)2+(pc)2 …where p=mvγp=mvγ. I'm probably pushing this formula because it has a close connection to the concept of “four-momentum”, a Relativistic notion that intrinsic energy can be thought of as the time component of a four-dimensional momentum vector. It's a very elegant concept, and definitely worth exploring in its own right; and it can be made to do the job here by rephrasing the original question appropriately. Bottom line, there may be conceptual purity in the latter approaches; but I don't think it's always worth the added hoops you have to jump through.

For a body’s mass to appear as if it’s doubled, we must take into account the relativistic effects. First of all, for a body with a mass of mBmB the following expression holds: E=mBc2=γm0c2=m0c21−v2c2−−−−−√E=mBc2=γm0c2=m0c21−v2c2 What we want is for mB=2m0mB=2m0 which means that 2m0=m01−v2c2−−−−−√2m0=m01−v2c2 the m0m0 term cancels out and we have 2=11−v2c2−−−−−√2=11−v2c2 4=11−v2c24=11−v2c2 and by further manipulating this expression and solving for vv gives us the solution 4(c2−v2)=c24(c2−v2)=c2 4c2−4v2=c24c2−4v2=c2 3c2=4v23c2=4v2 v2=34c2v2=34c2 and taking the square root on both sides, we end up with v=3–√2cv=32c So, if you accelerate the body to a speed equal to 0.866c0.866c then its mass will be doubled!

The question has been answered by others already. However, I’d like to point out here that ‘relativistic mass’ is just a term developed by physicists to make it easier for students to understand relativity. This just helps us to have an intuitive idea why can’t we travel through space faster than the speed of light. It basically says that as you travel faster, the relativistic mass increases and it becomes harder and harder to further increase the speed of the object. So this term has its pedagogical importance. However, it can be misleading sometimes. For example, if you say that the mass of the object increases as it travels at higher speed, you might plug this higher mass in the Newton’s gravitational law and think that if this object passes near another massive object, it will experience more gravitational force due to its increased mass than it would otherwise at lower speeds. This is just not true. Therefore, the only true mass of an object is the one we measure in the rest frame of that object.

It's not really correct say that the mass changes at all. It's more accurate to say that the inertia increases. Even then, the inertia only increases from the point of view (frame of reference) of an observer moving relative to the proton. Putting all this together, your question becomes “at what speed would a proton have to be travelling relative to me to have twice the inertia of a proton at rest relative to me”. And the answer to that is 0.866 c, where c is the speed of light. As an aside, the proton would experience itself exactly as normal but would measure your inertia to be twice your rest mass inertia.
